org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.handlers

Class MovementHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.handlers.MovementHandler

  • public class MovementHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    The MovementHandler class provides a central location for all movement-related as well as a couple data-related methods. Currently, MovementHandler is instantiated, but in the future, functionality could be made static.
    Author:
    Will (wrtc9)

    • Method Detail

      • move

        public void move(double lin,
                 double lat,
                 double rot)

      • move

        public void move(double lin,
                 double lat,
                 double rot,
                 int weight)
        Move sets the powers of all drive train motors using the parameters lin, lat, rot, and weight. Lin, lat, and rot are summed up (with positive or negative coefficients based on the wheels) and multiplied by the sigmoid of the total (sigmoid is translated to range from -1 to 1).
        Parameters:
        lin - linear component of the robot speed
        lat - lateral component of the robot speed
        rot - rotational component of the robot speed
        weight - weights sigmoid; input to sigmoid function is divided by weight

      • errorTransformer

        public double[] errorTransformer(double x,
                                 double y,
                                 double r)
        ErrorTransformer converts a set of coordinates to polar and then adds the complement of r. Practically, this is used to rotate a target point around the robot so the robot is virtually facing towards positive y. This, fixes an issue with x and y error.
        Parameters:
        x - x distance between robot and target
        y - y distance between robot and target
        r - rotation of the robot

      • getDcMotor

      • getSensorDetections

        public java.util.EnumSet<SensorDetection> getSensorDetections(float precision)
        GetSensorDetections finds which sensors detect an object within a distance of the variable precision.
        Parameters:
        precision - how close an object must be before it is avoided
